addressleaf.section:
from
e
q
u
majestie
e 22 of auguste 1592

To our trusty and welbelovid Thomas Bodley Esquire our Counsello
r
of the
Counsell of State
in the
United Provinces
in the
Lowe Countries

page.lettertext:
fol.279r
1592 22 Au
g
To M
r
Bodly
By the Queene:
Elizabeth R
Trusty and welbelovid we greet you well. Wheras by our l
re
s of the first of Julie,
we did geve you knowledge, of our Resoluc
o
n, for the putting in order of certaine nombers in o
r
paie in those Contries, to be in a readines for their marching to the Sea side, and from thence
to be transported into
France
, to the service of the
Frenche Kinge
: and that you shold enforme
both the
Stat
generall
, and Counsell there, of this our determinacion, and of the reasons that
moved us therunto, which might also move them, not onlie to allowe therof, but to yeld the
like Ayde on their part, to the Frenche Kinge, against the c
o
mon Enemie; And at the same
time also, we did will you to enforme
S
r
Frauncis Veere
, and
S
r
Thomas Morgan
, out of
whose charges, the greatest nombers shold be drawen, to put the said nombers to be in readines
untill the time we shold signifie our pleasure for their marching to the Sea side, and transpor-
tation into France. Since the receipt of which our l
re
s, we have by divers of yours for
answere therunto, perceived in what sort you did impart this our resoluc
o
n to the States
generall, finding them more unwilling to allowe of this o
r
intenc
o
n, then we thought either they
wold, or in reason they ought to have ben, and notwithstanding that they have by l
re
s of
theirs of the fiftenth of Julie, in s
o
me part expressed their misliking, yet we doubt not
but by our l
re
s of the xxiij
th
of Julie unto them, and by other our l
re
s of the xxviij
th
reiterating the just reasons that have moved us therunto, and our full answers made unto
their pretenc
, and nowe of late also, by our verball resoluc
o
n delivered
to
their Agent Mons
r
de
Caron, with the continuall necessitie of the French Kinge urging us for the publicque weale,
and as the cause nowe standeth even for Christendome they hav
i
g allowed of o
r
resoluc
o
n, will
willinglie geve their furtheraunce to this our purpose. And therfore nowe that we have
up
o
n intelligence of the French King
estate and his great necessitie, made full determinacion
to send our said forces according to our said l
re
s, without anie maner of delaie, as in like maner
also, we do send, other our forces out of this our Realme, into
Britaigne
, at this present. We will
you, as holding the place of our Counsello
r
in that State there, that you impart this
o
r
present
determinac
o
n to the Stat
, and that also you geve knowledge, and c
o
maundement in o
r
name, both
to S
r
Frauncis Veere, and S
r
Thomas Morgan, to whom you shall impart theis our l
re
s
w
ch
we doubt not, but that they will dutifullie see on their part
performed, as in like sorte
we looke that all other our governo
rs
, and Captaines under
o
r
paie, will do the like, and so w
th
all speed,
cause the nombers appointed, by former l
re
s and directions from o
r
Counsell, in our name sent to you,
to marche onwarde without anie delaie to the Seaside to
Flushing
, there to be imbarqued, to
passe into France w
th
their whole nombers, limitting unto them, the shortest daie you can appoint,
for the more hastie expedic
o
n by the advise of the said S
r
Frauncis Veere, and S
r
Thomas
Morgan, for their repaire to the seaside, where order is allreadie geven to have shipping for them, and
to make paiment to them according to the nombers, that shalbe readie there to be imbarqued, and that
shall imbarque. But yet nevertheles up
o
n s
o
me report
made unto us, of s
o
me preparacions in
Flaunders, nere to
Ostend
, yelding s
o
me suspic
o
n of evell purpose against that Towne, we thinke it
good to spare the sending of anie of the nombers, which were appointed to be sent from Ostend, wherof
mention was made to you before in the Articles sent from o
r
Counsell the seconde of Julie, whom
we wold have now forborne, to be sent at this present into France, but rather to be presentlie
directed to Ostend, there to serve, and
Captaine Lambert
, and
Buck
to repaire also to Ostend, where
we wold have you, to move the States verie urgentlie, to send s
o
me further nombers of theirs
thether, either strengthening the Towne w
th
more nombers, to divert the purpose of th'Ennemye,
or by reinforcing of the Towne, to withstand their Enterprise, which we wold have you
fol.279v
diligentlie and earnestlie to presse the Stat
unto, and namelie to cause s
o
me shipping to be sent
to that Coaste, for defence of anie enterprise against the Haven of that Towne. All
w
ch
we hope the States will earnestlie regard, considering the towne is theirs, and our
forces there by us maynetained, only for the defence of the same their towne, and not for
anie perticuler interest to o
r
selves. We wold have you also renewe to the States,
A purpose offered to arme certaine Shippes of Warre, to serve on the Coast of Bretaigne,
against the Spaniard
, which if they shall performe, we also will employe s
o
me good
Forces of ours, by Sea, to empeache the Spaniard
enterprises: In which matter we
require you to use all expedic
o
n both for their answere, and for their purpose, howe and
when, they will take this enterprise in hande and therof we require you to advertise us
with speed. Our further pleasure is that you shall geve c
o
maundement in our name to S
r
Thomas Morgan that wheras there are eightene Cannoneirs there in o
r
paie emongest
out footemen w
ch
have an overpaie of enterteynment, that the said xviij
ten
Cannoneirs
be sent awaie as percell of those nombers, that shall goe our of that Garrison, who
shalbe continued in like wages and paie in Fraunce as they be there in
Berghen
- And
because it may be objected that if they shold be sent awaie, there wold lack Cannoneirs
for the States Ordenaunce in Berghen you shall p
n
tlie move the States therin,
that they may send others to supplie those places if there be not sufficient there
allreadie, and herof ye shall also advertise S
r
Thomas Morgan. Of theis o
r
directions that concerne S
r
Thomas Morgan you shall do well p
n
tlie to advertise him
by extracting the same out of this our l
re
to you , which shalbe yo
r
sufficient warraunt
and discharge in that behalfe.
Geven under our Signet at Alldermerston the xxij
th
daie of August
1592
In the xxxiiij
th
yere of our Raign:
